issues.body:
> typos: send, sended

Good catch -- will fix.

> I think that the use cases should list a situation in which the client does 
> not expect to perform session resume, so it can inform the server of that by 
> sending the value 0.

Good suggestion! We can certainly add this. 

> The draft does not state what is the expected behaviour with tickets in 
> relation to post-handshake authentication.

As the extension is merely a hint to servers when deciding how many tickets to vend, I think this is out of scope for the document.

> The draft does not state if the extension is negotiated once per session or 
> its values should be reused for resumed sessions.

It's intended to be once per session, and we'll add that.

> The draft does not state how the extension interacts with Hello Retry Request 
> handshake. Can it be dropped/added/changed in 2nd CH message? What is expected 
> to happen when client does change it?

Also a good catch. Like other extensions that are not affected by the possibly updated ClientHello, it must not change. We need to specify the server side behavior, too.

> > Servers that support ticket requests MUST NOT echo "ticket_request"
> > in the EncryptedExtensions.
> 
> It's not spelled out what the client is expected to do when server does 
> violate this expectation. I'd say it should abort with unsupported_extension.

That seems reasonable to me.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
Document:  draft-ietf-tls-ticketrequests-06
Reviewer:  Dale R. Worley
Review Date:  2020-11-27
IETF LC End Date:  2020-12-03
IESG Telechat date:  Not known

Summary:

    This draft is ready for publication as a Standards Track RFC.

Editorial comments:

2.  Use Cases

   *  Parallel HTTP connections: To minimize ticket reuse while still
      improving performance, it may be useful to use multiple, distinct
      tickets when opening parallel connections.

To the naive reader, the ordering of the phrases doesn't seem to match
the logical ordering of the concepts.  Perhaps

   *  Parallel HTTP connections: To improve performance, a client
      may open parallel connections.  To avoid ticket reuse, the client
      may use multiple, distinct tickets on each connection.

--

   *  Decline resumption: Clients can indicate they have no intention of
      resuming connections by sending a ticket request with count of
      zero.

"have no intention" seems to me to suggest a decision that will not
change.  Since the future cannot be guaranteed, perhaps better wording
is "do not intend to resume", suggesting a current state that might
possibly change in the future.

   new_session_count  The number of tickets desired by the client when
      the server chooses to negotiate a new connection.

   resumption_count  The number of tickets desired by the client when
      the server is willing to resume using a ticket presented in this
      ClientHello.

If I understand the processing which is suggested correctly, when the
client sends a ClientHello, the server can choose to either negotiate
a new connection, or (if a ticket is present in the ClientHello) the
server can choose to resume the previous connection represented by the
ticket.  These two parameters provide the requested ticket count for
the two situations.

Assuming the above is correct, I would recommend changing the wording
slightly, as "when" suggests a fact which is true over an extended
period of time, whereas the provided counts are applicable in just this
one instance:

   new_session_count  The number of tickets desired by the client if
      the server chooses to negotiate a new connection.

   resumption_count  The number of tickets desired by the client if
      the server chooses to resume (using the ticket presented in this
      ClientHello).

(Change "the" to "a" in the last sentence if the ClientHello can
present more than one ticket among which the server can choose.)

I also note that if I understand correctly, this field's ability to indicate whether the server supports reuse at all is a key fact in order avoid both (1) the perceived need for a magic 0->1 mapping, and (2) scenarios where a client that supports reuse talking to a server that does not support reuse ends up alternating resumption and full handshakes.  Specifically, such a client will know whether to request 0 or 1 tickets for future resumptions against the server in question.

Many of the problems we currently have in this space (without any sort of extension) stem from the fact that the only data available to the client about server ticket policy is from the actual issued tickets, and since the server can issue/not-issue tickets for arbitrary reasons, it's hard to pick up a clear signal from that behavior.

This is #18 without ticket re-use text. This also includes changes from #17.

The following table outlines the ticket request values for a a client that wants 
N tickets and always attempts to race a connection across K paths.

| Client Scenario | new_session_count value | resumption_count value |

```suggestion
Having multiple tickets equips clients with enough tickets to initiate connection racing while
```

This is advisory text, so I would prefer that you avoid SHOULD.  Particularly for the resumption_count, which could equally be N (as it cannot apply in the absence of resumption, the value doesn't matter).

```suggestion
nevertheless negotiates a fresh session, the client might assume that any
```

RFC 6919 MIGHT WISH TO
I.e., I think this should maybe be a SHOULD.
Nit: I am not sure I would say "forced". Selected?
I tend to think this should be a MUST.
This did use normative language previously, but @martinthomson observed that this was primarily advisory text. In this case, if clients don't follow the advice, they may end up with zero tickets.
That seems reasonable to me! I'll fix it.
That seems reasonable to me as well (less choices to make for implementers). I'll fix it.
Can we clarify *when* the server expects to send these tickets?
Should this really be called a ServerTicketRequest? It doesn't seem like it's making a request, but instead sharing info.
It's the server's version of the "ticket_request" extension, so I think we should keep it!
That's elaborated on in RFC8446!
Does it? Specifically, I mean: is this the number of tickets I will give you *this* handshake? Or after you resume? Or ever? Or outstanding at one time?

reviews.author: tfpauly
reviews.body: Server expected count usage seems underspecified and explained.

comments.body: .... but more seriously, it's the amount the server expects to send in this connection. Suggestions for improvement are welcome!
Can the field explanations be grouped with their struct definitions?
Hmm, I disagree. Again, it's the server's "ticket_request" extension. I could live with `ServerTicketRequestHint.

"All of the above" is very vague. What is an implementation supposed to do with this value? My comments asked if it was for *this* connection or including future connections in this session, which doesn't seem clear.
The request hint is for "this connection," so this surely applies to "this connection" as well.
Sure!
@tfpauly Clarified -- please have a look!

What's the rationale for this being a normative MUST? I.e., what would happen if the server didn't send the extension, but did provide the number of tickets that the client wanted? That would look like a server that didn't want to use the request, but got lucky. It seems like it could be a SHOULD, since it's hard to enforce?
Better, thanks!
Less options (and therefore consistency) for server implementers, mainly. This makes the behavior clearly, "if you use this extension, send one in response."
Right, makes sense. Sounds like a SHOULD, though. MUST feels like something that can result in a protocol violation error, which seems (to me right now) to be hard to enforce.
If it's a SHOULD and a server doesn't do it then clients can't determine whether or not the hint was consumed, which is the point of echoing it back. As a MUST, its use is clear.
(I don't claim that this is useful for the client to know, as MT points out. Only that there's ambiguity if it's a SHOULD.)

I generally like the rule of thumb that a MUST needs to be enforceable; you can point to an implementation that doesn't follow the MUST and identify it. 

As you say, echoing back the extension is a hint that the request was consumed, and clients MUST be able to handle it not being present (in case it wasn't actually used or consumed). Therefore it is impossible to distinguish between a server that just didn't consume the request, and a "bad" server that ignored your MUST flagrantly. I agree that we definitely want servers to send this, but it feels like a SHOULD since it doesn't allow anyone to detect misbehavior or send an error.

This really only needs to say what happens if you do something.  That is, clients might choose to send 0 (in either field) and that results in them getting 0 tickets.  That's OK if that is what they want.  So explain the consequences, but don't recommend a particular course of action.

Sure, I get that most people doing resumption will want more tickets, but there are plenty of reasons not to ask for more tickets.  Maybe they want to do a full handshake next time.

The reason I would use for making this a "MUST" is that it ensures that clients have a better idea about when new tickets are likely to be replacements.  If the server says 2 and then sends a third ticket, the client might infer that the first ticket it received is no longer good.

I think I would prefer a MUST here as well. That way, if a server does not send it we know that it is not compliant to this specification. Also, when implementing the server part of this, engineers don't have to decide whether to send this or not.
I added some clarifying text that describes what happens when resumption_count is less than the number of parallel connection attempts.

```suggestion
: The number of tickets the server expects to send in this connection.
```

This doesn't need to be in response to the client's extension.  Fewer words.
Good suggestion -- thanks!
Eh, okay. I still think that it's clear enough as a SHOULD, but I can live with it.
